question: Question_A_06
statement:
For what values of the parameter \emph{a} does the matrix

\[\begin{bmatrix}
1  &  0  &  a\\
-1  &  1  &  1\\
2  &  1  &  0
\end{bmatrix}\]

\emph{not} have an inverse?
sols:
A requirement for a matrix to be invertible is that its determinant is
non-zero. Conversely, non-invertible matrices have zero determinants.
Therefore, if we compute the determinant of the matrix and force it to
be zero, that will give a requirement on \emph{a}. We can compute the
determinant of the matrix by cofactor expansion (we will choose the
first row),

\[\begin{vmatrix}
1  &  0  &  a\\
-1  &  1  &  1\\
2  &  1  &  0
\end{vmatrix}
=1
\begin{vmatrix}
1  &  1\\
1  &  0
\end{vmatrix}
+a
\begin{vmatrix}
-1  &  1\\
2  &  1
\end{vmatrix}
=-3a-1.\]

We want this determinant to vanish and so we require -3\emph{a}-1=0 or
\emph{a}=-1/3. Therefore, if \emph{a}=-1/3 then the matrix will have a
zero determinant and thus \emph{not} be invertible.
hints: How do we relate information about inverses to determinants?
